name: ML-G10
keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard with 5 function keys, numeric keypad and arrow keys.
ports: 2 joystick connectors, 2 cartridge slots, Tape (1200/2400 baud), RGB, composite  and RF TV video outputs, Centronics, audio output
description:
The ML-G10 is a MSX 2 computer. It is a compact version of the ML-G30 without the disk-drives.

There is a painting program built-in the ROM.

More info needed!

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HEATH 19 TERMINAL (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>$595 was the price in kit form, F.O.B. Benton Harbor...<br> The assembled version, called Zenith Z-19, costed $895. An expensive price, not compatible with a   home computer budget. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Students have a heap particularity which we cared about"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IIE VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Promotional picture. Notice the dual floppy drive module on top of the case, inspired by the Franklin <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/museum/computer.asp?st=1&c=646" target="_blank">ACE 1200</a><p class="petitgris">Roberto Isiri</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Prior to the 6800 computer, MSI manufactured 8" floppy disc units.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 6</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>She seems quite happy with her new MB-H1 !<br> Do you think japanese girls used to bring their H1 to school ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN TANDY CATALOGS (1993)</strong></font><br><blockquote>WP-3 model</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Olivetti M10, the portable professional micro-computer, here comes why."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The computing answer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Hyperion is a true portable weighting in at only 18 pounds. It is light on the eyes with its European amber screen and styling. But heavy on performances with many standard features which are expensive necessities for other personal computers. And all for a price  that's less that you'd expect...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (APR. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #4 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBRAIN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Newbrain brochure only offered two models:<br><br> Model AD: with display<br> Model A:  without Display <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b>   </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - FEB.1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, SEPTEMBER 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Valric-Laurène was the french importer of the Spectravideo SV-318.</blockquote>

MEGA RAM DISK 256|||from DDX (Brazil)|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEGA RAM DISK 256</strong></font><br><strong>> from DDX (Brazil)</strong><br><blockquote>This is the famous Megaram cartridge made in Brzail, used to play all Konami cracked Megarom games.6401999243</blockquote>

Panasonic  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). These expansions are for MSX2 systems.</blockquote>
Sony HBI-232|||RS232c cartridge|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SONY HBI-232</strong></font><br><strong>> RS232c cartridge</strong><br><blockquote>Used to connect serial printers.</blockquote>

Yamaha mouse #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This mouse was compatible with all MSX systems. It connects to the first Joystick port.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br>  It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br>  Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>

emulator.name: fMSX official Homepage
emulator.description: fMSX is a portable MSX emulator ported on : Amiga OS, Mac OS, MS DOS, OS/2, Sony Playstation, Risc OS, Towns OS, Unix / X, Win95 / NT, X68K.

emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.
emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and  MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
